comments.commentBody: Not really - it just means your vote is diminished less.  It's still diminished.  The only answer I can justify is a weighting of 1.0 for everyone.

Yes, Obama fell into the "join the winning general" trap and gave in to trying in Afghanistan what seemed to have worked in Iraq. No use to mention how gullible Bush was in believing the Cheney scripted WMD drama so Cheney could get his revenge of Bush Sr. for not taking the Baghdad detour in 1993 and rid the world of the evil dictator. Obama was weak because he left the decision to the general(s), because he did not have the experience to decide on his own. Tragic, yes. More soldiers died than 'needed'. Won't happen again with Obama. Will happen again in the future.

And yet the man who circumvented the chain of command and in 2009 lobbied Congress, wooed corporate elites and charmed the MSM into supporting our bloody and doomed surge in Afghanistan is soon to be the newly-divorced president of Princeton University and Mr. Obama will begin his second term in two months. Weak?

If in the judgement of history, President Obama proves to be "no Truman" then we should all be grateful. No one individual is more responsible for the huge political influence of the American military, its bloated, budget-busting spending and the perpetual wars we find ourselves fighting in order to justify its existence.

To Doug:

Lincoln actually may have been our president MOST bedeviled by our military: otherwise, our civil war might have been a far less bloody affair and might have been over in two rather than four years.

And you give too much credit to presidential candidates who win: they're not only poorly prepared for national defense, as you say, but they're usually not too well grounded in the political system, either. Mr. Obama, a very likeable guy and quite brilliant, should have captured this election with more than a rounding error in well over 125 million votes cast if he could have sold moderation more effectively to the center-right, something he failed to do utterly; and Romney, who didn't win but almost did, failed at what could have been a rout based on Mr. Obama's performance, and he failed because he didn't master the political system well enough to effectively counter Mr. Obama's superior ground game. Mr. Obama remains the classical example of a great candidate who turns out to be a mediocre president, while Romney will become a footnote avatar to the bad candidate who could have been great if he'd been elected.

Welcome to America.

Petraeus had political ambitions; he not only was accustomed to telling Congress and the president what to do, but he did not hesitate to publicly disagree with Obama and in the end Obama took orders from Petraeus because Obama is a weak leader.

General Petraeus was the most dangerous general since MacArthur and Obama demonstrated that he is no Truman.This was not a joke as you suggest; good riddance to a general whose self regard and ambition knew no bounds.

I share your story. I turned 65 in year 2000. Asked to retire from my position as hospital physicist. I could detect a loss in short term memory. They asked me to stay on till we found a replacement. Due to the highly technical nature of the position it took 3 years to find a competent replacement. In that time I made an error that led to a $300,000 law suit. Even with that I was asked to work as a consultant for 2 more years to help my replacement.

It is important to be able to retire at 62-66 years.
I haven't heard Moishepipik since my mother used to call me that when I was a kid. Thanks for that.

"For all members of Congress over 60, pull out their desks and chairs wherever they work.. Let them conduct their business standing up."

Better yet, let them hang 5/8s sheet rock for a couple of years. And do it fast, no screwing around, forty hours a week. A 4X8 foot sheet weighs 73 lbs. a 4X12 sheet about 112 lbs.

Our political system if still infested with Republicans who hate Social Security and Medicare and they want to privatize former and voucherize the latter until it disappears. If they could raise the eligibility age for Social Security to 70 they would jump at the chance. Someone who is 30 does not really expect collect Social Security but you start thinking about retirement by 55. I am 78 and I retired at 67 and could have retired at 65. I worked longer because by retirement savings, mostly in mutual funds took a nosedive and money I thought would be there was not and Social Security became more important. Yet I was lucky. As an attorney I did not have to climb, bend and lift. Although after 40 years of work I was getting tired, I could not put in long hours and work was no longer fun.

By 65 I wanted to retire and I was not what I was at 60. I decided to hold on for 2 more years, the hardest I ever spent. I often thought how must it be for a factory worker or a construction trades worker or a laborer whose back and arms and knees screamed. What of all those low wage workers trying to live in the years between when you can collect Social Security and the ability to work ends. I have an educational idea. For all members of Congress over 60, pull out their desks and chairs wherever they work.. Let them conduct their business standing up. Plenty of Americans stand on their feet for 8 hrs/day. See how it feels. Congressional pensions should not start for 15 yrs after retirement.

Overall life expectancy, that is, from birth, has increased, that's true.  But what is relevant to Social Security is the life expectancy of people who have reached age 65.  It's a rather surprising fact, but the number of years left for a person who reaches age 65 today is not much more than the number of years left for someone who reached age 65 in, say 1935.

Life expectancy of a 67 year old is not 35 years. The average is probably less than half that. So I disagree with your facts/assumptions. It would make a lot more sense, if a change is needed, to raise the early social security age to 63 from 62.

So, what happens if the Social Security runs out for someone who is either careless or lives really long into old age, in other words doesn't die soon enough? Death panels and a firing squad?

Of course, if I'm a 22 year-old kid and I have 60 years of trying to find and hold onto jobs ahead of me, maybe the firing squad might sound inviting.

I assume that you are not a 22-year old kid.

While I agree with your sentiment, I disagree with your facts. There is no question that people are living much longer, on average, than when Social Security was first enacted. It is fitting and appropriate that we raise the retirement age.

What we should retain, for those who choose to elect it, is the ability of people to take Social Security early while assuming the risk that there benefits will not be sufficient in the long-term.

It is naive to believe that we can support people for up to 35 years of retirement after 48 years of work.

Mr Obama reelection  has one message loud and wide.This is to bridge ever widening inequality among American people.Whether this is in the domain of college education,health care for old or young,right to choose in case of pregnancy or women empowerment.Republicans are opposed to each of these, aspired by a vast majority.Obama is free to pursue a Progressive agenda that he fought for during his campaign.In his first term Obama compromised with the Republicans in arriving at consensus for issues which Republicans shun.This was an utopia and Obama paid a heavy toll in 2010 mid-term election by loosing numbers in the US House of Representatives. Obama was at the verge of remaining one term President as propounded by the Senate Minorty Leader.American people reposed their confidence in the President and granted him a second term to complete his unfinished agenda.Republicans false 'Mantra' the 'trickle down' has not worked since 1950.All progressive economists have negative opinion about it and therefore Obama must avoid the Republicans trap to fall in it.The elderly,irrespective of their life vocation,deserve medical care so that  the evening of their life is not confronted with a fear of filthy and lingering ending.This is a priority for the Obamacare that the President achieved after a fight of half a century.This equality in elderly health care need not be compromised.All  talks about the expectancy of life, at birth or at retirement, are only to eclipse  inequality.

We need to fix the media! Social media has become increasingly more reliable and honest and a better source of information about tough policy choices. Yet many Republican-influenced think tanks and sites continue to omit important facts and employ outrageous fantasies to put forth discredited ideas. They ignore truth and assign partisan sides, reducing the arguments to political debates and this season's favorite frame of false equivalency.

Romney just ran a campaign entirely build on lies so bold that real corporate job-creators had to call him out about his lies. His party was silent. They will be more silent about the things they have been screaming about for years, reducing the middle class benefits of Medicaid and social security. And silent about solutions: Grand Junction, CO is the poster child for controlling health care costs; initiated by physicians.

The GOP is like a wounded lion. Instead of accepting the people's judgement, they are ready to strike back! They will destroy the people's security and mobility through legislative action, whenever they can. Ryan will be given a waiver to continue as budget chair. That signals Republicans think no rules must impede their dismantling of America's Promise.

The problem with means-testing for Social Security is that it then becomes a welfare program and, like all other means-testing programs, the people who are accepted because they have little means become "takers" in the minds of the people with power.

Why not use means-testing for this issue about early retirement. Those workers who earn the least are often those who have been denied decent health care through our irrational for-profit insurance system*. They must be allowed to retire at the current age of 66. Better off workers could be slotted into a sliding scale reaching 70 for the highest paid. If we combined this approach with a lifting or raising of the cap on taxable wages above 106.000$ we could extend the life of social security and dry the tears of our crocodile Jeremiah's in the Tea Party and on Wall Street.

*Here's an interesting companion statistic. 72% of American's are classified as Non-Hispanic Whites. But 80% of all citizens older than 65 are Non-Hispanic Whites. At the same time the percentage of our population that reaches 65 is the lowest of any other Industrialized county. We all have industry... we are all to a degree post industrial but they have single-payer health systems.

Its time for the Takers to Take.
"The only hope is that they die off before before they hit the Medicare eligibility age.. " maybe that's the hidden agenda.

Mr. Krugman.. you ask what will happen if we raise the Medicare eligibility age.

You go on to say we will save only a small amount as younger seniors are relatively healthy but they will face higher out of pocket costs. Very true. But there is one more dynamics that will come into play which will add to this effect you are describing.

The seniors will postpone or ignore necessary medical care due to the increased expenses. So when they ultimately come into the Medicare pool they will end up costing that much more completely nullifying any savings.

The only hope is that they die off before before they hit the Medicare eligibility age.. which is pretty macabre.

One study on medicare medical cost stated $3,800 per year until the terminal year when it rose to $24,000. So if my math is right, you would save about $23 Billion per year by increasing age eligibility( 10 years of medicare per person and 6 million per year added). Or you could get the insurance companies( who are just a pass through) out of the medicare drug program and save the same amount. Since people who make it to 65 usually last for at least a year, taking a year off is just wrong.
The reason medicare cost more then in 1986, the year of the last increase, is because we are now doing open heart surgery, replacing hearts(or getting their first one like Cheney), knee and hip replacements, etc., not even counting all the "little rascals" running around for $3,000 plus a pop.
Medicare is either important or not. If it is, make all income, not just certain categories, taxable and get on with it.
By the way, I'll get my pitchfork and torch and march on Washington if they try to give me a voucher to a connected insurance company so they can take $2,000 of my social security money as profit.

The crux of the argument lies in 3 prescient statements made here.

In regards to receiving Social Security benefits:
"Living longer doesn't imply the individual will work longer."
There can be a gap between the time anyone's employment possibilities come to an end and Social Security benefits take effect.
Increasing the retirement age enlarges the length of the gap.

In regards to receiving Medicare benefits:
"Again, living longer doesn't imply the individual will work longer."
Medical benefits are received through plans provided as a part of the employment process. When employment ends then medical coverage ends.
Increasing the eligibility age enlarges the length of the gap.

Employment problems created by automation, outsourcing, and increases in the size of the work force all make actual employment opportunities more uncertain.
"Do we really want to pressure people to work past age 65, given that we do not have enough jobs now?"
Persons retiring open up employment opportunities on down the line to younger generations.

All of the above problem situations can be resolved by means other then placing unacceptable and/or life-threatening burdens upon older persons.

In the last analysis, it is simply the decent thing to do for the citizenry and the nation at large.

Thanks MNW.  You sparked an additional thought.  For those whose health fails at ages after 65 but before Medicare starts (caused either by work or lack of work), the cost of Medicare benefits at the later retirement age could easily be much higher than if Medicare had been allowed to start at 65.  Access to Medicare at ages 65 and 66 could improve health and significantly reduce Medicare costs later on.  It would be self-defeating to try to reduce costs by raising the Medicare retirement age for those people.

For Social Security, the increased retirement age affected the level of benefits not the age when benefits could start. The first start age was 62, and is still 62. The benefit level at any start age, however, is lower under the new law. Of course, the lower benefit lasts for life. Increasing the retirement age was really just a way to lower benefits, the argument about people living longer was a convenient way to rationalize it. Living longer doesn't imply the individual will work longer. Increasing the retirement age, however, does lower costs.

For Medicare, if we increase the retirement age, it's my understanding that Medicare benefits will not be available at any level until the later retirement age. However, when Medicare does become available, at the later retirement age, the level of benefits would be the same as under the old law. This is qualitatively different than what happened under Social Security. Costs for the individual would only be lower for a year or two, not for life as with Social Security. Again, living longer doesn't imply the individual will work longer. As you indicate, the cost impact on Medicare would be modest.

Do we really want to pressure people to work past age 65, given that we do not have enough jobs now?

Dr. Krugman,

You say that Medicare costs must be controlled. Would the following type of proposal work?

Democrats agree to a hard cap on Medicare growth (say, 1% below GDP, on average), and in exchange Republicans agree to allow Medicare to pursue all reasonable cost-saving measures.

This would give the cost certainty and reductions that Republicans are looking for and, according to you, would have no real impact on the quality of Medicare.

Why is Paul Krugman about the only informed, sane economist writing for the public in the United States? Once again, he goes to the facts, and ends up with recommendations which are both more humane, and more financially sound.

In other words, if President Obama does what's best for our economy, he will also not raise the age to receive Medicare or to retire.

A better idea would be to increase Medicare payment requirements for seniors with high incomes.

The best idea is to quit allowing advertising which is so detrimental to the health of Americans who have never tasted a healthy diet and don't have a clue to how much better they would feel (after a time) if they just ate healthy food. Many poor people in the world use very little health care in their old age because they stay healthy to shortly before they die.

No one makes a profit off this - that's why we are not discussing it. But the most humane way of improving health is for the chemical companies to stop putting poisons in the air, water, and earth; for farmers to quit using chemicals to fertilize which destroy fresh water sources; and for us to harness the sun and heat from the earth for heating/cooling.

We must quit exploiting the commons - or we will not survive.

Congress has lost touch with reality because they are an "elite" class of people, beholden to the wealthy people and entitites that fund their campaigns.

Have you ever talked to your congress person? Have you ever written them and gotten a response back that appeared not to be a boilerplate response put together by a staff person?

When the average representation is one Congressional representative per 700K persons, they are anoynomus to us, and we are to them.

We need to vastly increase the membership of Congress, which hasn't changed in numbers since 1929, and yet our population has roughly tripled since that date. More and more we are getting a system that can be characterized as "Taxation with Inadequate Representation."

I can't come up with any more rationale way to improve Congress's performance, other than to hope the behave more in line with the Public's will.

But as Upton Sinclair famously wrote: "It's hard to get a "person" to do something they're paid (i.e., campaign funds) not to do."

The problem is congress itself. They have lost touch with reality and ordinary people. Reducing benefits and extending the time before hard working citizens can retire by a congress that lavish benefits upon itself is an unbelievable breach of trust.

Congress has forgotten its purpose, to serve the people of the country and instead exists to serve itself.

I agree absolutely with you, Sophia. One of the best and most readable books presenting the lives of people in this situation is Nickel and Dimed, by Barbara Ehrenreich. It should be required reading by everyone, both those who have power over others as well as voters who will elect those people. If you haven't read it, get it. She's a wonderful and charming writer and remarkably incisive. The book is a fast read, too.
Single Payer Option RULES!!!

Thank you Sophia for pointing out ageism...you can be older, (up to a point), but you're right..heaven help you when you start to look too old. Invisible? Try, does not exist. For women, the expiration date comes a heck of a lot sooner.

More older women living in poverty?.....you betcha.

Welcome to our grand, disposable, throw-away society. We waste everything and value what? Oh yeah...CEOs, stock-holders and always, always the bottom-line.

The powerful, wealthy elites need to hear from real people, people who know what it's like to labor, people with high-stress jobs - and those often don't pay very well. They need to hear from actual economists, like Dr. Krugman, not politicians with an agenda

As far as life spans are concerned, a lot of my friends are already dead (I'm a boomer.) They weren't wild and crazy people either (well not all of them!) But environmental issues, job stress including the necessity to retrain and switch careers, the lack of economic security adds up and affects health and lifespan.

This may hit women particularly hard - we're underpaid to begin with, often have dual responsibilities (both work and home) and perhaps have to work two or more jobs to survive. That takes a toll.

Many workers ave gone through several recessions and downsizings and probably have spent significant periods of time without health insurance. Some of us are at or near the poverty line - wages simply haven't increased enough to afford basics over the last 30 years or so. The median income level in the US isn't the "middle class" that earns $250,000, it's more like $50,000 and many, many Americans earn much less than that.

Also, there is ageism. Once you start looking old, it's that much harder to find work and in the case of women it seems we start becoming invisible.

No way should the retirement or Medicare eligible age be raised. To lower costs increase the pool - offer Medicare for all.

One problem here is that it can be hard to tell when someone is at the end of life.  Two years ago at 87 my dad had, during a 6-month period, a stroke, gall bladder surgery and another procedure, pneumonia, a feeding tube, a broken hip, shingles, and two eye surgeries.  He is now feeling much better, looking forward to his 89th Christmas.  During that same period my mother started showing some signs of Parkinsonism, and was dead with no hospitalizations in a year.  Sometimes you just don't know.

Thank you. I've read a lot of the usual political positions in these comments (and I agree with them for the most part). But if we are to get on top of the problem, we'll need practical solutions that we can implement.

You've suggested a number of workable solutions that would cut costs significantly. I'd like to see the debate focus on practical solutions rather than political posturing.

It's funny, the GOP touts itself as being the fiscally responsible party. But do you hear them suggesting anything like what you've outlined? Nope. Why not? Isn't it better to cut costs without hurting people than it is to cut costs by hurting people? I would think the answer to that would be a no-brainer.

Not for the GOP, apparently. And for my fellow Dems - please, start focusing on practical solutions, such as the ones George S has put forward. It's a given that people deserve decent healthcare. By letting the GOP focus us on that debate, we're letting them frame the debate. Affordable, quality healthcare for all is the starting point. Period. So let's see how we can deliver it to everyone in the most efficient, effective manner. That's what the debate ought to be about. Let's get practical AND remain humane. That's how we'll win.

The cost of Medicare can be lowered, as Mr. Krugman argues. Negotiating drug prices will save tens of billions, as would requiring adherence to best practices, i.e. only paying for those procedures that are proven effective and least costly. With traditional fee for service,  there are no cost controls, no consideration of what is the most efficient use of medical care dollars. Also, the last weeks/months of life use an inordinate amount of health care dollars. Instead of hospitalization of terminally ill patients, paying for hospice care or home care would be both less costly and more humane.

That is the 3rd death at that intersection in the past 2 years. Lepoldo Hernandez died in January of this year while crossing the street, and a cyclist, 24-year-old Nicola Djandji, was struck and killed in 2011. It is a residential neighborhood, but motorists speed through the light on the way to the Williamsburg Bridge. This is not a coincidence. Something needs to be done to improve safety for pedestrians in the neighborhood. Grand street traffic lights need to be adjusted to slow traffic and the pedestrian crosswalk missing from the east side of the intersection should be painted/installed. We also need more cops watching for speeding violations and frequent DUI checkpoints.

I totally agree, Ken, but let us remember that many of the fundamental ideas in Obamacare ARE Republican ideas and it was not until it became OBAMA-care that the Republicans disowned it. For Republicans, the overarching motive is to return to power any way they can; it's not the ideas they reject, it's leadership by the Democrats. Period.

Why is it that all of the creative juices of the Republican right must be used to attack the welfare of their fellow citizens? Rather than proposing new and inventive ways to reduce the cost of healthcare, they are trying to expose more peple to its devastating impacts. Rather than insisting that we provide health care through the most cost effective method available, they are blocking any effort to abandon the outrageously expensive combination of private insurance and multiple layers of medical provider cost centers.

It is so difficult slogging through a morass of corporate greed, elitist hubris and political obstructionism to arrive at a destination already reached by the vast majority of the world's industrialized nations. Republicans must come to understand, though, that even if we must struggle every step of the way we will reach our goals. If we get there without them, more the shame on them.

And in the meantime, why on earth do those of us who get part or all of our health care paid by employers get a tax break on it?  Not only is our group coverage generally cheaper and better than that of people who must buy their own on the open market, but they also have to buy it with after-tax income.  It's what we're used to, but it's not fair or right.

I'm a strong believer in Krugman's previous pieces where he talks about how unregulated health insurance companies are doomed to a death spiral to the bottom where all insurance companies eventually eliminate anyone who has any risk of having a medical bill at all.  But there's a related topic that never gets any hearing: why on earth do we expect employers to provide health care?  This puts a drag on employment and makes our companies less competitive compared to those in countries with national health insurance programs.  Health care should be nationalized for all ages, and only by twisting yourself into a logical pretzel can you argue otherwise.

Maybe, I don't know your sources, but other advanced countries spend half as much per capita on medical care, so it might be a good starting point to cut our per capita spending by 50% in 2013 dollars.
Hmm, a full 50% lower cost for years more life expectancy as compared to the USA doesn't sound like failing. It sounds like AMAZING SUCCESS.
The average cost of health care per person in other industrialized countries is 40% of what we pay. In the 10 years I have followed this topic it has gone down from 50% to 40%.

"The answer is to do what every other advanced country does, and make a serious effort to rein in health care costs."

Unfortunately, a look at the health-care finances of "every other advanced country" reveals that they are all failing at controlling rising health-care costs. Every one of these systems is struggling to remain solvent.

So now what?

Ryan Braun plays average defense in LF.  Trout plays excellent defense in CF.  That's an enormous difference.  Just looking at OPS+, Posey's was 172 and Braun's was 159, so it wasn't even close.  But had Braun actually been the better hitter, there is a big positional adjustment to be made for catcher vs left field, yes.
Despite getting off before the season, Ryan Braun carries the PED taint, and, clearly, no statistician can quantify that.

I think that the really difficult argument for a statistician to make is the one that has Posey winning over Braun.

It's hard to conclude that Braun's year was much different than Trout's. The main argument that Trout has over Cabrera was his speed, but Braun has that covered.

I think it's agreed that Posey won because he is a catcher.

So the tough question is this:

How good does a catcher have to be offensively to be considered as good as someone with Cabrera's power and Trout's speed ?
Very well put.

You ask, "isn’t it odd that the same people who demagogue attempts to help Medicare save money are eager to throw millions of people out of the program altogether?" It's not odd at all. It's not even a contradiction. Reducing entry into Medicare and simultaneously throwing recipients out of Medicare simply extends the damage to two otherwise mutually exclusive populations (until those in one group age into the other). It's just part of the destruction that Republicans such as Palin (the one whom Senator McCain want a heart beat away from his prospective presidency) are trying to achieve. Insurance companies love guys like that, and reward them one way or another.

What's odd is this: here in the land of press freedom, reporters are not allowed to include such observations in their routine reporting. Only experts like you, and pundits have that kind of access to the media.

And, of course, readers whose comments vanish within hours of submission.

I forget where in the Constitution it says, "Congress shall always balance the budget at all costs."  Is it right after insuring domestic tranquility, or buried somewhere in one of those sections about Congress levying taxes?  I'm sure it must be there somewhere, what with so many people saying that's what our government is supposed to do.  Promoting the general welfare doesn't seem to be a very high priority for many Republicans, so obviously that can't be in the very first paragraph describing what an ideal United States government would do.

So much misinformation...lower income workers have a lot more stress than execs. Some activities diminish health but often they diminish life as well. So smokers die earlier. The obese die earlier. Alcoholics die earlier. Sedentary living isn't a good predictor. Drug use depends on the drugs, some drugs kill early, some don't.

Executives don't have higher rates of cardiac problems. They do have better medical care to test for cardiac problems. And perhaps more motivation to prove they have cardiac problems because they can retire early using private disability plans if they do.

Health insurance companies can't control costs: hospitals, physicians, drugs, etc. So most often, they control expenditure by denying coverage.

Actually, plenty of medical care is extremely cheap to deliver. Diabetics are not really treated, there's nothing to cure. They are managed which means that they physicians order tests, prescribe standardized medications, don't look too hard to determine what kind of diabetes they have and try to convince the patient to change their unhealthy ways. However, diabetics die earlier than the abstentatious. Most could be managed by a wii program or an app on their mobile phone.

I don't think that there are going to be many improvements in this country. But there will be in other countries.
They are all, every single one of them without exception, doing a much better job of it than we are.  Just that margin would change the whole problem.

Obama did not swallow the myth. He chose not to hang his reelection on fighting myths head on.

This leaves much work to do. But at least it can be done without Romney.
